insights.title: "AI as a Tax and Social Object"
insights.subtitle: Fiscal Management of AI Gains
insights.summary: AI ceases to be just a growth driver and becomes an object of fiscal policy through the introduction of an AI tax. This reflects a shift in the perception of AI as a source of redistributable rent to compensate for job losses and social risks.
evidence: Emergence of a political-financial framework for an AI tax to compensate for job losses
Discussion of taxing incremental AI gains in investor discourse
Shift of AI topic from growth to fiscal and social hedging
insights.nonObviousConclusion: The introduction of an AI tax may radically change incentives for investment and AI adoption, shifting the focus from profit maximization to socially responsible development. This will create new challenges for companies in managing tax risks and social legitimacy.
insights.educationImplication: It is necessary to develop competencies in AI economics and fiscal policy to prepare leaders capable of managing the socio-economic consequences of AI.

insights.title: "Agent Engineering Instead of Chatbots"
insights.subtitle: From Generation to Verification
insights.summary: There is a transition from simple chatbots to complex agent systems with multi-level verification and quality control. Engineering now includes tool orchestration, MCP schemes, and Act-Verify-Refine cycles, which increase the reliability and reproducibility of AI products.
evidence: Mainstream agent engineering with a closed Act-Verify-Refine loop
Formal specification and integration of external solvers/verifiers
Growing demand for verification engineers of agent systems
insights.nonObviousConclusion: This shift creates new professional niches and standards requiring interdisciplinary knowledge in ML, security, and QA. Companies that do not adapt to new methodologies risk losing competitiveness.
insights.educationImplication: It is necessary to implement programs on agent engineering and AI system verification, developing skills to work with complex production loops.

insights.title: "Legacy Software Under AI Threat"
insights.subtitle: Modernization and Rent Threat
insights.summary: Vertical integration of AI models and tools threatens traditional legacy software providers, especially in the Cobol and mainframe segment. Code modernization by agents lowers migration barriers and revalues long-standing competencies.
evidence: Anthropic's statement on Cobol modernization and its impact on IBM
The threat of legacy development dequalification becomes a market fact
The market perceives AI as a risk to incumbent software rents
insights.nonObviousConclusion: The reduction of legacy software rents may lead to capital redistribution and changes in the IT industry landscape, stimulating growth of new players and services. Companies must invest in retraining and AI modernization integration.
insights.educationImplication: It is important to train specialists in AI modernization of legacy systems and managing the transition to the digital age.

insights.title: "New Protocols and Conflicts in the LLM Industry"
insights.subtitle: Model Borrowing and Protection
insights.summary: Escalation of conflicts around permissible borrowing in LLM leads to enhanced protection measures, including rate limits, watermarking, and legal sanctions. This changes informal norms of open science and benchmarking, creating new barriers to collaboration.
evidence: Anthropic's statements about illegal extraction of results by Chinese DeepSeek and MiniMax
Increasing pressure on open science and benchmarking norms
Implementation of technical and legal model protection measures
insights.nonObviousConclusion: Tightening control may slow innovation and knowledge exchange but simultaneously stimulates the development of new standards and compatibility protocols. This creates challenges for global cooperation and competition.
insights.educationImplication: It is necessary to train specialists in AI ethics, intellectual property, and legal regulation of AI technologies.

insights.title: "Energy â€” The New Limit of AI Expansion"
insights.subtitle: Infrastructure Bottlenecks
insights.summary: Growth of AI infrastructure hits limits of power grids and power gear, becoming the new 'chip shortage.' This shifts focus from GPUs to energy infrastructure and creates risks for data center scaling.
evidence: Backlogs in power gear and grid connection equipment
Shift of the screw in AI data center construction towards electricity
Energy and cooling as fundamental limits of AI expansion
insights.nonObviousConclusion: Companies and regions with developed energy infrastructure will gain competitive advantage, and investments in energy will become critically important for the AI ecosystem. This may lead to geopolitical shifts in the distribution of AI resources.
insights.educationImplication: It is important to train specialists in energy and infrastructure for AI, including interdisciplinary knowledge in electronics and resource management.

insights.title: "Institutionalization of AI Safety"
insights.subtitle: From Incidents to Control
insights.summary: Real AI incidents lead to increased regulatory pressure and institutional control of safety. This changes institutions of responsibility, disclosure, and interaction with law enforcement, making safety part of mandatory control.
evidence: Canada summons OpenAI over ChatGPT case and mass shooting
Institutionalization of disclosure and interaction with law enforcement
Increasing requirements for guardrails in military AI procurement
insights.nonObviousConclusion: Strengthening control creates new barriers to rapid AI adoption but increases public trust and reduces risks. Companies must integrate compliance and safety into product strategy from the start.
insights.educationImplication: Programs on AI safety, law, and ethics are needed to prepare specialists capable of working under strict regulation.

insights.title: "Hardware Optimization through LLM"
insights.subtitle: AI Improves Infrastructure
insights.summary: LLMs are beginning to be used to optimize compilation and GPU cores, improving infrastructure performance and reducing TCO of training and inference. This changes AI's role from resource consumer to active enhancer of the hardware stack.
evidence: K-Search for GPU kernels and IntOpt for IR optimizations
LLM agents increase infrastructure performance
Reduction of training and inference costs through LLM optimization
insights.nonObviousConclusion: This shift may redistribute competitive advantages between cloud providers and hardware manufacturers, stimulating new innovations in hardware and software stacks.
insights.educationImplication: Training specialists at the intersection of AI and hardware engineering is important for developing and implementing optimizations.
